metadata.title: LinkedIn API + Python = Programmatically Publishing | by Alessandro Berti | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: How to publish a post through LinkedIn API and Python

all_paragraphs: I and other two friends of mine have a podcast and, each time we publish a new episode, we need to spread it around over socials (a.k.a. SPAM).

The repetitive action of copy&paste of the very same post over different socials, bother us a lot. So we decided to develop our web-app that let us deliver a single post over multiple platforms in one shot!
We smoothly succeeded in the integration of Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and our Telegram channel.
When you program, You would like to develop your application in the fastest way possible. Once it works, then you start refining the code.
This haste, however, necessarily leads to the loss of some important details hidden in docs. And guess what? Your code won’t work and you will go crazy.
After a few days, you find out the “why” it wasn’t working. Your reaction type can be clustered in two distinct sets:
Which one do you belong to?
So,my mission is to present a super-practical-step-by-step guide to interacting with LinkedIn API through Python. That’s it.
Go to the LinkedIn Developers platform.
Verify your LinkedIn page by click on “Verify”
Click on “Generate URL” and follow the few steps requested by LinkedIn
Once done, if everything is OK, you’ll get the “Verified” on the main page of your app
Move to “Products” and enable both “Share on LinkedIn” and “Marketing Developer Platform” products
⚠️ By clicking on “Marketing Developer Platform”, you’ll receive on your primary email, the following Request Form.⚠️
⚠️ You need to fill it, otherwise, LinkedIn isn’t going to authorize you to manage your page! ⚠️
Be patient, and wait for the answer. LinkedIn will contact you by email.
My request has approved in 2 days
You have successfully created and verified your app!
Until we wait for the response, let’s go on with other stuff!
Now click on “Auth”. Here you find your Client ID and the Client Secret.
For the moment, just remember where they are.
Set up your “Authorized redirect URLs for your app”.
Be careful at the following syntax! /auth/linkedin/callback is mandatory!
It’s time to get your hands dirty with some code!
To get your Access Token, you need two REST calls:
Just have a look at the following URL. Wait before copy&paste!
response_type=code. It’s already ok, just copy it.
cliend_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID. Insert your Client ID specified in the Auth section of your LinkedIn App.
redirect_uri=https://example.com/auth/linkedin/callback. Insert the Authorized redirect URL you specified in the Auth section of your LinkedIn App.
scope=w_member_social,r_liteprofile. The scope is very important! It specifies the permissions you need.
If you are planning to interact just with your own profile in “reading mode” then, the r_liteprofile permission is enough.
If you are planning to exploit LinkedIn API to publish posts in your own profile, you need “write permissions” (i.e. w_member_social).
However, you can compose permissions as in the example: scope=w_member_social,r_liteprofile.
If you are planning to use LinkedIn API to interact with your page, please keep reading until the ⚠️⚠️ ACHTUNG ⚠️⚠️ paragraph.
Permissions change according to your needs. In case you want to further investigate:

If you are on the right way, you’ll get redirected here:
Once clicked on “Sign In”, you will get redirected again to an empty page!
⚠️ → Now, take a look at the new URL of the empty page! ← ⚠️
Copy it to a note. Is it something like that, right?
Copy the value of the code parameter (i.e. YOUR_CODE); we need it to correctly invoke the POST.
The previously described GET allows you to manage ONLY your own profile account, NOT your page. To manage your page, you need to:
⚠️ If you try to invoke the following GET with the w_organization_social permission BUT you haven’t still received the approval to the “Marketing Developer Platform”, the GET will fail!⚠️
Thus, you have to wait for the approval by LinkedIn.
Now, it’s POST call time! Let’s do it through bash!
You already know what to do. Right?
Insert the YOUR_CODE obtained from the GET as the value of the code parameter.
Also, insert YOUR_CLIENT_ID and YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET. Just repeating: “You can find them in the “Auth” page of your LinkedIn App…”
Follows the POST response together with the Access Token!
If you requested the Access Token along with the w_organization_social permission, the above response will contain also a refresh_token field.
Copy the access_token field (and don’t lose it!)
From your LinkedIn App, click on “Auth” and then on “token inspector”.
Copy in the form your Access Token, then click “Inspect”.
Check that the permissions correspond to the ones you specified in the GET call.
If it’s like that, you have done!

The id field is… Guess what? Your Profile ID! In my case it is: idBfR6bf7d

This last script will work as soon as the review of the “Marketing Developer Platform” has been accepted by LinkedIn and you have re-generated a new access token with w_organization_social permission!
I’ve presented a very simple case, but since it works, you can start hacking it and try any other more specific LinkedIn API based on the python code provided!
Hope this super-practical-step-by-step-guide has been useful!
